[25,36,26] Del(2:5) Bro, I would recommend this more than the in-person teachers you need to pay $500 per month. del nums[2:5] If sets don't have index numbers then what are we supposed to enter inside pop, I experimented a bit and s.pop() jut removed the first value from the set, is that all it does? anna masth ga unnaye ANNA Sir you really help us working from the trash level hats off to you :) LIST:

append() Adds an element at the end of the list

clear() Removes all the elements from the list
copy() Returns a copy of the list
count() Returns the number of elements with the specified value
extend() Add the elements of a list (or any iterable), to the end of the current list
index() Returns the index of the first element with the specified value
insert() Adds an element at the specified position
pop() Removes the element at the specified position
remove() Removes the item with the specified value
reverse() Reverses the order of the list
sort() Sorts the list

SET:

add() Adds an element to the set
clear() Removes all the elements from the set
copy() Returns a copy of the set
difference() Returns a set containing the difference between two or more sets
difference_update() Removes the items in this set that are also included in another, specified set
discard() Remove the specified item
intersection() Returns a set, that is the intersection of two other sets
intersection_update() Removes the items in this set that are not present in other, specified set(s)
isdisjoint() Returns whether two sets have a intersection or not
issubset() Returns whether another set contains this set or not
issuperset() Returns whether this set contains another set or not
pop() Removes an element from the set
remove() Removes the specified element
symmetric_difference() Returns a set with the symmetric differences of two sets
symmetric_difference_update() inserts the symmetric differences from this set and another
union() Return a set containing the union of sets
update() Update the set with the union of this set and others

If it is correct hit me a like "Variables of the same value are given the same memory address" can sometimes work against you. Learned it the hard way from a code like this:

a=[1,2,3]
b=a
for i in range(1,4):
for num in a:
b.append(num+i*10)

The intent was to make a list of this pattern: [1, 2, 3, 11, 12, 13, 21, 22, 23, ...]. But since python uses the same memory address for a and b, appending list "b" will also change list "a". With the for loop trying go through a list that keeps expanding each iteration, the loop becomes infinite. To avoid this issue, make "a" a tuple (a=tuple(a)) after the line "b=a'. This will result in "a" and "b" having different addresses and less likely to be mixed up. Can we find the number inside box with help of I'd ??? Interesting How to create spool file in python ? 5 functions from math module (got this from help > math)
ceil(x, /) - Return the ceiling of x as an Integral. This is the smallest integer >= x.
floor(x, /) - Return the floor of x as an Integral. This is the largest integer <= x.
pow(x, y, /) - Return x**y (x to the power of y).
sqrt(x, /) - Return the square root of x.
sinh(x, /) - Return the hyperbolic sine of x. "Run Module" worked but for whatever reason when I pressed the shortcut "F5", it didn't work.

# This one is to understand - Break
for i in range(5):
if i ==3:
print("From here it goes out of the loop")
break
print("Hello", i)
print("Did you understand how 'break' works?")

# This one is to understand - Continue
print('\n')
for i in range(5):
if i ==3:
print("From here it goes back to the beginning of the loop")
continue
print("Hello", i)
print("Did you understand how 'continue' works?")

# This one is to understand - Pass
print('\n')
for i in range(5):
if i ==3:
print("This is the missing 3")
pass
else:
print("Hello", i)
print("Did you understand how 'pass' works?") to print first 50 fibonacci number :

def findPrime():
num = int(input("Enter a number : "))

if num == 1:
return print("Not a Prime number")

for x in range(2, (num // 2) + 1):
if num % x == 0:
print("Not a Prime number")
break
else:
print(f"{num} is a prime number")


findPrime() The fastest way to find prime numbers is by using "Sieve of Eratosthenes" method.
def sieve(n):
prime = [0 for i in range(101)]

ctr = 0

for word in words:

ctr += 1
return ctr

Okay I want to share my story of installing Numpy on my system. I took me 6 complete hours to figure out how to do it. I hope sharing my experience will save your time.
1. I typed ' pip install numpy' in cmd and it showed a warning 'you are using pip version 20.2.3, however version 20.2.4 is available'. I installed the newer version but it wasn't that necessary.
2. However I kept gettng a messase everytime i tried installing numpy saying "microsoft visual c++ 14.0 is required." So what you have to do here you have to install
(i) Visual studio 2019 using visual studio installer. Don't delete the visual studio installer app.
(ii) Visual C++ redistributable from the official microsoft website
3. Then you have to run the visual studio installer app again to modify the visual studio installed on your machine.Go to workloads and choose 'Desktop development with C++'' and tick the 'MSVC v142-VS2019 C++....' and 'windows 10 SDK' options ( try to tick the recent ones).
this installation will take around 30 min.
4. Then you restart your machine and type 'pip3 install numpy' in cmd. Mine worked after this. Thanks Navin Reddy sir. Without your amazing video I would not have the motivation to overcome the difficulties associated with installing a simple package which will enable me to do 2D -3D array calculations on computer

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The values that are given as input are log(base10) values
so if input is 2 the actual value is 10^2=100(^ means power)

logspace() follows Geometric Progression

It uses log(base 10) values. In simple Terms

Eg : logspace(2,5,3)

here 2 means 10 raised 2 times which is 100 (Prior Knowledge on log is required here)

and 5 means 10 raised 5 times which is 100000

In Geometric Progression nth term is a*r^(n-1) (^ means power

here a value is 100
n is 3
last term (nth term)= a*r^(n-1)=100000

100*r^(3-1)=100000
100*r^2=100000
r^2=1000

r=10*sqrt(10)=31.622776601683796

so the 3 numbers are
100*(31.622776601683796)^0=100.0 ,
100*(31.622776601683796)^1=3162.2776601683795
100*(31.622776601683796)^2=100000.0

So The 3 numbers are 100.0,3162.2776601683795,100000.0


Like If You Got Clarity Those who want Clarity on linspace()
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Linspace has separate stuff hidden in it It is similar to Arithmetic Progression.
Eg: linspace(0,7,3)
in arithmetic Progression we have nth term or last term is a+(n-1)*d

In this case a is 0 and n is 3
l=a+(n-1)d=7¬†


0+(3-1)d=7
2d=7
d=7/2¬†=3.5
d is common difference between 2 adjacent values

So the result we get is
0.0 , 3.5 , 7.0
Hope This helps If you are in search of clarity

Lots of love and respect sir !‚ù§ for the first I did not understand Pass by value: We pass the copy value of the object and changing the copy of object will not change the original object.

Pass by reference: We pass a reference or memory to the function and changing the object in the function will ultimately change the original object as they both reference to the same memory location.

However in python,
Concept of pass by value or pass by reference is dependent entirely on the mutability of the object passed to the function.

If the passed object is immutable like a number or string. i.e changing them would create entirely new object. Passing by value comes to play.

However in case of mutable objects like lists. Changing the value will cause it to change the original object directly. This feature portrays the pass by reference. For example: if we have variable a and b outside the function and inside the function I want to change the value of a and b. Can we do that with single statement or I have to use Globals()['a']=somevalue and lobals()['b']=somevalue? # Local Vs Global

# Global
a=10
def something():
# Local
a=15
print("in fun",a)
something()

print("outside fun",a)

# if we don't specify local variable and print a inside the func it will access the global variable a

# Global
a=10
def something():
print("in fun",a)
something()

print("outside fun",a)

# in order make the local variable a as global it is possible , once if we change as global

a=10
print(id(a))
def something():
global a
a=15
print(id(a))
print("in fun",a)
something()

print("outside fun",a)




# we want a local variable a and change the global variable a so in that case we can't use the keyword global to achieve that.
# want to change the global variable without affecting local variable then:

a=10
print(id(a))
def something():
a=15
globals()['a']=40
print(id(a))
print("in fun",a)
something()

# print Fibonacci sequence of n length - example: 0 ,1 ,1, 2, 3
# a function to print list- user has the option to provide the length of the list he wants.
n=0
def print_list(lst):
print(f"You asked for a Fibonacci sequence with {n} numbers. Your list is below-: ")
if len(lst) == 1:
print(f"{lst[0]}", end='')
elif len(lst) >= 2:
i = 0
while i <= len(lst) - 2:
print(f"{lst[i]}", end=',')
i += 1
print(f"{lst[i]}", end='\n')
if lst[-1] == 89 and n > 12:
print("That's all we got. Cannot print a list with any value > 100 !")

print_list(fib)

count += 1
if count % 2 != 0:
factorial *= -1
elif number == 0:
factorial = 0
else:
for f in range(1, number+1):
factorial *= f

previous = 0

previous = new
new = result

return x

2- but it will print hello calc (the module name )

Only criticism I have is in the explanation of Class and Instance. It's not that you don't get there, but it's almost like you're skirting around the simple answer: Seems that the best way I've seen this described is to say that when you ask someone about a thing... What is this? It's a phone. That's it's class. The class is phone. We know from this, the basic attributes (It's size, weight, and color), but when we ask what TYPE of phone it is, we're then talking about an Instance. IT's instance is the Motorola Nifty Call ™, and it has the same attributes as the class (phone), but in the instance of it we see that things are different. Bigger or smaller, more memory, faster processor etc. This leads us into understanding inheritance, and polymorphism in later videos.

Then I had create one more class of result and I want avg of the student class sum but it is giving error to us Very good sir why the parents class constructor is not implicitly get called when child is instantiated like in java or c++ In the case of duplicate methods between parent classes, using super() will not take any arguments to choose which to use, and will always go from left to right as you list them when defining the child class.
ie. C(A, B) will pull from A in the case of duplicates, and C(B, A) will pull from B in the case of duplicates.

In the case of duplicate methods between parent classes, you can choose which of the parent classes to use a method from by explicitly calling the method within the child class. Instead of using super().method() you can decide which instance of the duplicate to use by naming it explicitly. If your class inherits A before B, like in C(A, B), but you want to use a method from B that also exists in A, use B.method() to use it.

super(). looks like a good shortcut for when you know you will not be dealing with choosing between duplicates, and you don't want to explicitly mention which class to call from. When considering MRO, does it consider the name of the class? Does it sort according to the alphabetical order to find what is the first on the left? Nothing expalined about duck typing waste of time Three Types of Duck Duck Duck Super this is the most confusing tutorial about duck typing i have ever seen May be this helps who doesn't get the duck typing ...

1. class HP:
2. def laptop(self):
3. print("From HP brand")

4. class Dell:
5. def laptop(self):
6. print("From DELL brand")


7. class Student:
8. def Shilpi(self, brand):
9. print("This is a student")
10. s2.laptop()


11. s1 = Student()
12. s2 = HP()
13. s3 = Dell()
14. s1.Shilpi(s3)

Important Points :
A. In student class , we have provided an argument that is "brand" , and in (line : 14) , we have passed an object (belongs to dell class)
B. We could provide the object of class HP(line : 12) or class Dell(line:13) , because both have function laptop().
C. As we know , it doesn't matter what object from which class we are providing in (line : 14) , Then what matters ??
D. The object which we are providing as an argument(line : 14) should have the function laptop(). [This matters only , that's it]
This is Duck typing.

class examhall:
@abstractmethod
def instrument_box(self):
pass
#'bring instrument box'

def water_bottle(self):
print('bring water bottle')

class students1(examhall):

def maths(self):
print('ok, i sure need one for the test')
#so let me define an instument box
def instrument_box(self):
print('pencils, compass, ruler etc')

class students2(examhall):

def social(self):
print('but i dont need one anyway')
#but since its compulsory, let me bring an empty one
def instrument_box(self):
print('empty box') #or just pass

s1 = students1()
s2 = students2()

s1.maths()
s1.instrument_box()

s2.social()
s2.instrument_box() I see many are still confused with the concept and also with "how is it different from duck typing". Here is an example to get it cleared.

This is an exam 'hall' and there are students from 2 diffrent 'classes' seated. Class A has a maths test, Class B has social.

The invigilator says that to enter the hall, every one must carry an instrument box. Now students of classes both A and B must bring one even if B class don't have its use. So the class A will have a set of compass, rulers, pencils etc in it. But since students of class B don't have any use, they will just bring one with a pencil or even just empty (pass) because its compulsory to bring one in to be in the hall.

If a parent class has an abstract method, every child must also have one. So each child will have to define one of thier own.

In duck typing, It isn't necessary to define the parent class method for each child classes. it just simply have to point to the class where the particular method lies. Here we would have to define for each.

pta nhi kiya kri jarha hoooo Concept is not reached Summary:
abstract method is a method which only has declaration and doesn't have definition.
a class is called abstract class only if it has at least one abstract method.
when you inherit a abstract class as a parent to the child class, the child class should define all the abstract method present in parent class.
if it is not done then child class also becomes abstract class automatically.
at last, python by default doesn't support abstract class and abstract method, so there is a package called ABC(abstract base classes) by which we can make a class or method abstract. Thanks for the video. but you can make it better The same program i have executed but still the same error

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
import inspect

class sample(ABC):
def sam(self):
pass
print(inspect.isabstract(sample))
game = sample()

OUTPUT---> False

In the above example, we can see that the sample class inherits ABC (Abstract Base Class) but by using the inspect module of python it returns false as it doesn't have an abstract class and we are able to create a class from the sample class
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
import inspect

class sample(ABC):
@abstractmethod
def sam(self):
pass
print(inspect.isabstract(sample))
game = sample()

OUTPUT---> True

In the above example, we can see that the sample class inherits ABC (Abstract Base Class) and has one decorator abstract method sam by using the inspect module of python it returns True which is correct.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

05:52 To solve the problems of user comprehension and execution stopping, use a try-except block in Python.

07:52 Exception handling allows us to handle errors and execute alternate code when an error occurs

09:41 Always ensure to close a resource that you open in a try block.

11:35 Exception handling in Python allows execution of code, whether an exception occurs or not.

13:39 Exception Handling in Python

15:35 Exception Handling in Python with try, except, and finally blocks

step 2 - find a min index i.e lowerBound + upperBound / 2
step 3 - now we have to check that the mid value is same or not with the value we are seaching for
step 4 - next change your lowerBound or upperBound
4.1 - the value we are searching for is smaller or bigger than the mid value
4.1.1 - if your value is smaller change the upperBound to midindex
4.1.2 - if your value is bigger change the lowerBound to midindex
step 5 - again find a mid value
repeat step 4 """

return True
else:
if arr[mid] < n:
lB= mid+1
else:
uB = mid-1
return False

def binary_search(sequence, item):
begin_index = 0
end_index = len(sequence)- 1
while begin_index <= end_index:
midpoint = begin_index + (end_index - begin_index) // 2
midpoint_value = sequence[midpoint]
if midpoint_value == item:
return midpoint
elif item < midpoint_value:
end_index = midpoint -1
else:
begin_index = midpoint + 1
return None

def search(list,n):
l = 0
u = len(list) - 1

if n > list[u]:
return False
if n < list[l]:
return False
if n >= list[l] or n<=list[u]:
while l <= u:
mid = (l + u) // 2
if list[mid] == n:
return True
else:
if list[mid] <n:
l = mid+1
else:
u = mid-1
return False

@staticmethod

def bubblesort(list):

for i in range(len(list)-1,0,-1):

if list[j]>list[j+1]:
list[j], list[j+1] = list[j+1], list[j]

return list

Btw, Great video Sir as always! Thank you!! Liked your video but I wish you made the code completely dynamic, instead of having for i in range(5) have for i in range(len(list)) In Python you can swap by writing just
nums[i], nums[minpos]=nums[minpos], nums[i] Teaching future Python users to use and conceive for..loops as if they similar to other language's loops is instilling bad habits and poor reasoning that will hinder their progress greatly. In Python, for...loops are iterators not counters, and they ought to be understood as "for each_elements in a_set do something on each_elements", not "for index from 0 to len(nums)) do something on nums[index]" as in C language.

--------- Python code starts here ---------

def selection_sort(unsorted_list):
"""
A far better way that mimics the actual principle
behind 'selection sort', that is sorting by selecting
items one after the other according to an ordering
function
"""

# (optional) work on a copy to keep the original list unmodified
lst = unsorted_list.copy()

while lst: # for as long there are items in the list
extracted_value = min(lst) # find the smallest value
del lst[lst.index(extracted_value)] # remove it from the list
yield extracted_value # outputs it on demand


numbers = [5, 3.14159, 8, 6, 7, 2]
print(list(selection_sort(numbers))) # [2, 3.14159, 5, 6, 7, 8]



# the above function can be easily generalized to use any arbitrary ordering function
def extract(n, *, func=min):
while n:
extracted_value = func(n)
del n[n.index(extracted_value)]
yield extracted_value

# Some examples
from functools import partial

reverse = partial(extract, func=max)
characters = list("Python".upper()) # in reverse alphabetical order
print(list(reverse(characters))) # ['Y', 'T', 'P', 'O', 'N', 'H']

import random
shuffle = partial(extract, func=random.choice)
players = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charles"]
print("The first to be randomly chosen is", next(shuffle(players)))
print("The second to be chosen is", next(shuffle(players)))
print("And the last to be chosen is", next(shuffle(players))) So i noticed that you sort by index when you assign minpos to I as opposed to nums[i]. I liked your tutorial, however one phrasing of yours gave me headache: You described the return value of s.accept() as the client socket. This is weird and indeed wrong. I was thinking: How can the client c send stuff to the client, and why is it called in the server script? Puzzling. So I found in the documentation: socket.accept()

Accept a connection. The socket must be bound to an address and listening for connections. The return value is a pair (conn, address) where conn is a new socket object usable to send and receive data on the connection, and address is the address bound to the socket on the other end of the connection.

So it is actually something like an 'extra socket object" specifically for communication (send/receive) in that exact communication between server and client. If you've started a new Django 3.1+ project and are using older tutorials or guides, it's likely to come across the following error on your command line:
NameError: name 'os' is not defined
Starting with Django 3.1, the startproject command generates a settings.py file that imports pathlib rather than os on the top line.

The quick fix is to import os at the top of your settings.py file:
# settings.py
import os # new
from pathlib import Path
The better fix is learn more about how pathlib works and update your BASE_DIR, DATABASES, STATICFILES_DIRS, and other files to use the newer, modern approach.

OR

In settings.py file on the top you will see
from pathlib import Path

Here we need to enter 2 numbers, add them & print result in new page.
1. In the home.html create a form to add 2 numbers home page.
a. Need 2 text fields to get values & button to submit it.
2. Need a page to display the results (result.html) - create it.
3. Created a new page, need to register in "urls.py".
4. Now, page is created & registered in URL's => now we need logic for it.
a. Create a function to add in "views.py" which gets the response from "home.html
b. And return to "result.html
5. Finally, in "result.html" receive response in a variable.
6. DONE.

# This function adds two numbers
def add(x, y):
return x + y

# This function subtracts two numbers
def subtract(x, y):
return x - y

# This function multiplies two numbers
def multiply(x, y):
return x * y

# This function divides two numbers
def divide(x, y):
return x / y

# This function modulus two numbers
def mod(x, y):
return x % y

# This function floor division two numbers
def floor(x, y):
return x // y

# This function exponential two numbers
def exponention(x, y):
return x ** y

print(" ")
print(multiplicationResult)
print(" ")
print(divisionResult)
print(" ")

The video showcases the beauty of datatype interplay in python and why using the right kind of datatype is important. The conversion of one datatype into another is known as type casting and it has two types:
i) Implicit type casting
In this type of type casting, the type of the variable is changed implicitly (automatically without specifying) by the interpreter. Datatypes in python follow a hierarchy and the "lower" datatype is converted to a "higher" datatype if and when need be. The hierarchy of datatypes is chosen such that there is no loss of data.
ii) Explicit type casting
In this type of type casting, the variable datatype is changed explicitly (upon specification) by the programmer. This is done for various reasons such as data manipulation to achieve a certain objective or to perform operations on datatypes of two different hierarchies. Explicit type casting allows one to cast from a higher datatype to a lower one, something which implicit typecasting does not allow. 22 Day 5 of #100DaysOfCode.

To make a program intuitive to use, it must be able to interact with a user, that is why today we learnt how to take inputs from a user in python. All good programs cater to the needs of the hour rather than executing the same code again and again. Taking inputs from a user is the most basic method of integrating the usage environment in a program.
The input() function in python helps us achieve this. This function pauses the execution of the program when called and returns a string value entered by the user in the terminal. A string can be given as an argument to accompany the function call and the user gets prompted to give an input. This can be useful to let the user know that the program is waiting for them or what kind of input we are expecting.
The function returns a string but this string may* be type cast into the datatype of our choice using the corresponding functions necessary for typecasting such as int() float() tuple() etc.
As such we can make our program interactive. good bhai Thnks bhai you are amazing Day 6 of #100DaysOfCode.

Today we learnt about strings and brushed over for loops. (function only)
Strings are "like" but not exactly arrays of characters. Each individual character of a string can be accessed in the same way as an element of an array can.
Strings may be enclosed in a pair of double quotes, a pair of single quotes, three pairs of single quotes or three pairs of double quotes.
A string enclosed in a pair of single quotes can freely use double quotes inside of it without the need of using escape sequences and vice-versa for a string enclosed in double quotes. A string enclosed in three pairs of single or double quotes can freely use single and double quotes inside without the need of escaping them, as long as they are not three consecutive quotes of the same kind as we started the string with.
Enclosing a string within three pairs of quotes has the advantage than we no longer have to use the escape sequence for the newline character and can simply jump to the next line in the compiler internally within the string without getting an error.
A string can be input directly till it receives a command from the terminal using the input() function.

An interesting observation was that the multiline comment in python is also made within three pairs of quotes, the only difference is that this is not assigned to any variable. This naturally raises the question, does python treat multi-line comments as stray strings? That is, does python allocate memory for multi line comments, and simply skips over them so as to not interrupt the code?

edit: Yes indeed is the answer to the above question, all of the questions in fact! Multi line comments are also called "docstrings" or "documentation strings."
The python interpreter treats multiline comments as normal strings and allocated memory to them, but since the strings are not assigned to any variable, the functioning of the code is left superficially unaffected, but deep inside the kernel the program requires more memory and more time to execute since it has to create a new (probably large) string object Day 7 of #100DaysOfCode.

The code `print(nm[-4:-2])` will output a substring of the variable `nm` starting from the fourth-to-last character up to, but not including, the second-to-last character.

Explanation:
- `nm[-4:-2]`: This is a Python slicing notation. It extracts a substring from the variable `nm`.
- `-4`: Specifies the fourth-to-last character in the string.
- `:-2`: Specifies up to, but not including, the second-to-last character.

So, it prints the characters at positions `-4` and `-3` in the string `nm`. The result will be a two-character substring.

Here we learn how to slice strings into substrings. The technique will be particularly useful when we are working with large strings and string slicing forms the basis of string manipulation.
To get the length (int) of a string we use the len(stringobject) function. This returns the exact number of characters inside a particular string. (Question: Does it include null characters as well?)
To get a substring from a string by slicing we use the format stringobj[a:b] where a is the lower limit and b the upper. The substring includes the character at the 'a'th index till the character at the 'b-1'th index.
(Question: Is strobject[a:a+1] equivalent to strobject[a] since the former returns a string and the latter a char)
If a>=b then the returned string is null
If a<0 then we replace a by a+len(strobject) and b<0 then we do the same. This is called negative slicing.
We also brushed over looping over a string using a character variable using the syntax
for ch in range stringobject:
statements
end

Answer to question 1
Yes, null characters form parts of the string itself hence all null characters are treated at par with regular characters

Answer to question 2
In both cases the return type is string even for strobject[a] hence it was said string is "like" an array of characters, not an array of characters. Day 8 of #100DaysOfCode.

Strings are immutable
String methods return a new string operated on a string object, they dont alter the original string
string.upper() -> touppercase
string.isupper() -> true or false
.lower() and .islower()
.capitalize() -> Caps first char and lowers ALL other chars
.title() -> Caps all inital chars of words and smalls other chars
.split(string2) returns a list by splitting the given string on every occurrence of string2 (excludes string2 from the list)
.swapcase()
.strip() => removes trialing and leading whitespace characters

.rstrip(string2) removes string2 from the END of the string object only
.find(string2 or char2) returns index of first instance of string2 or char2, if not found returns -1
.replace(oldString, newString) or (oldChar, newChar)
.count(char or string) counts number of occurrences of argument provided

import pytz
from datetime import datetime

# Set your local time zone
local_tz = pytz.timezone("Asia/Karachi")

# Get the current time in your local time zone
current_time = datetime.now(local_tz)

# Format the current time as "hour:minutes:seconds"
formatted_time = current_time.strftime("%H:%M:%S")

# Print the formatted local time
print("Your local time is:", formatted_time)

# Check the hour of the current time and print the appropriate greeting
hour = current_time.hour

if 5 <= hour < 12:
print("Good morning!")
elif 12 <= hour < 17:
print("Good afternoon!")
else:
print("Good evening!")

In the first line, we import the `pytz` library, which helps us work with different time zones. Then, we import the `datetime` module, which allows us to work with dates and times.

Next, we set the `local_tz` variable to your local time zone, which is "Asia/Karachi" for Kunjah, Punjab Province, Pakistan (you can write your location). This line tells the code which time zone to consider when getting the current time.

Then, we use `datetime.now(local_tz)` to get the current time in your local time zone. This line captures the current date and time information.

After that, we format the current time as "hour:minutes:seconds" using `strftime("%H:%M:%S")`. This line takes the current time and converts it into a formatted string.

Finally, we print the formatted local time using `print("Your local time is:", formatted_time)`.

To write a program that returns "Good morning," "Good afternoon," or "Good evening" according to the time, you can use an `if` statement to check the hour of the current time and then print the appropriate greeting. Here's an example:

```python
hour = current_time.hour

if 5 <= hour < 12:
print("Good morning!")
elif 12 <= hour < 17:
print("Good afternoon!")
else:
print("Good evening!")
```

In this code, we use the `hour` attribute of the `current_time` variable to get the hour component of the current time. Then, we use `if`, `elif`, and `else` statements to check the value of `hour` and print the corresponding greeting. import time

The timing for greetings like "Good morning", "Good afternoon", "Good evening", and "Good night" can vary based on cultural norms and personal preferences. Here's a general breakdown:

Good Morning: Typically used from around 5 AM until around 12 PM (noon).

Good Afternoon: Usually used from around 12 PM (noon) until around 4 PM.

Good Evening: Commonly used from around 4 PM until around 8 PM.

Good Night: Typically used when it's time to go to bed, which can vary widely depending on personal habits. It's often used when it gets dark or before someone goes to sleep.

Detailed Summary for [List Methods in Python | Python Tutorial - Day #23](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo) by [Merlin](https://merlin.foyer.work/)

Learning about list methods in the 100 days of code challenge. Explaining append, sort, and reverse methods with examples.

[00:00](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=0) Learn List methods to manipulate Lists
- Understand the important List methods
- Use .append method to add elements to a List

[00:52](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=52) Python Lists - Adding, Sorting and Reversing
- Use .append to add an element to the end of a list
- Use .sort and .reverse methods to sort and reverse a list

[02:04](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=124) Explains three different list methods in Python
- The 'l.index' method returns the index of the first occurrence of a list item.
- The 'l.count' method counts the occurrence of a given item in the list.
- The 'l.copy' method creates a copy of the list.

[03:12](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=192) Copying list in Python can cause unexpected modification
- Assigning one list to another creates a reference, not a copy
- Modifying the copied list will also modify the original list

[04:11](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=251) Avoid using references in Python programming
- Creating a reference can cause unexpected changes in the original object
- Beginners should use .copy() method when creating a new list

[05:11](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=311) Learned about the 'insert' and 'extend' methods in lists
- Insert method adds an element to a specific index in the list
- Extend method adds a list to the end of an existing list

[06:33](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scWc3F8LbOo&t=393) Learn to concatenate lists in Python
- Use extend() method to add elements of one list to another
- Use + operator to concatenate two lists and create a new one

Today in this video 24, I learned about Python tuples, which are ordered, unchangeable collections of data items. 2. t.count() counts the number of instances inside tuple.
3. t.index() gives the first index of an occurrence. Start of search and end of search can also be given to index function.
4. all functions of list are valid for tuples Day6 of #100DaysOfCode. Today in this video 25, I learned that tuples are immutable, so to add, remove, or change their items, I need to first convert them to a list, manipulate the list, and then convert it back to a tuple. I also discovered that tuples can be directly concatenated without conversion. Additionally, I explored two built-in tuple methods: count() to find the number of occurrences of an element, and index() to find the first occurrence of an element. It was interesting to understand the unique features and limitations of tuples.

def SayMorning(time):
hour = int(time.split(":")[0])
if hour <= 12:
return "Good morning sir"
elif hour >= 13 and hour <= 17 :
return "Good afternoon sir"
elif hour > 16 and hour <= 21:
return "Good evening sir"
else:
return "Good night sir"

#function to check if the answer is correct
def check_answer(question_number, answer):
if answer.lower() == answers[question_number].lower():
return True
else:
return False

#function to play game
def play_game():
total_prize = 0
for i in range(len(questions)):
print(f"Question{i+1}:{questions[i]}")
answer = input("enter your answer: ")
if check_answer(i, answer):
total_prize+=prizes[i]
print(f"Correct! You won ${prizes[i]}")
else:
print("Incorrect. Better luck next time")
break
return total_prize

#function to ask the answer if they wanna play again
def play_again():
play_more = input("Do you want to play again(Y/N)")
if play_more.lower() == "y":
return True
else:
return False

#game loop
while True:
total_prize = play_game()
print(f"you won a total of ${total_prize}")
if not play_again():
break

Today in this video 28, I learned about string formatting in Python using the format method and f-strings. The format method allows for more precise control over the formatting, such as specifying the number of decimal places. F-strings, introduced in PEP 498, provide a convenient way to embed Python expressions directly inside string literals for formatting. By prefixing a string with 'f', it becomes an f-string, making it easier to interpolate variables and expressions.

# Function For KBC
def kbc(q=2 ):

# Printing Question in terminal
print("Question : " , list[q][0], "\n", list[q][1], "\n", list[q][2], "\n", list[q][3])
# Getting Answer (input)
ans = input("Please Choose an Option: ")

while True:
# Condition For Answer (A)
if ans=="A" or ans=="a":
# If The answer is Correct Then Do What

print("7 Crore.")
# If The Answer is Wrong Then Do What

break

# If The answer is Correct Then Do What

# If The Answer is Wrong Then Do What

# Condition For Answer (c)

# If The answer is Correct Then Do What

print("7 Crore.")
# If The Answer is Wrong Then Do What

break


# Condition For wrong input for Answer
else:
ans = input( "\n"+ "Your Question is : " + list[q][0] +"\n" + list[q][1] + "\n" + list[q][2] + "\n" + list[q][3] + "\n" + "Please Choose Correct: " )


# Running the Function

Output=class set List: It is a collection of ordered data
Syntax: list1=[1,4,"Gitam",6,"college"]
list2=[] # creates an empty list

Tuples:A tuple is an ordered collection of data.
Syntax : tuple1=(1,2,"college",9)
tuple2=() # creates an empty tuple

Set:A set is an unordered collection.
Syntax: set1={1,2,3,4,5,"hello","tup"}
set2={(1,8,"python",7)}

Dictionaries: A dictionary is an unordered collection of data that stores data in key-value pairs.
dict1={"key1":"value1","key2":"value2"}
dict2={} # empty dictionary In this video lecture, we learnt about set datatype which is very similar to lists, but it is immutable, does not allow duplicate values, can not access set elements using indexing or slicing like lists, most importantly, sets are unordered. It's like a JHOLA(BAG) in which there is no guarantee to get the elements in the same order each time. To create a empty set set() method is used. a={} creates empty dictionary, not empty set. set- order doesn't matter 6:05üòÇüòÇ The method related to sets are:-
1) union()---->creates a new set with the unique elements from both the sets
2)update()----->applied on a set itself and it also adds unique elements from the both the sets into one of the sets
3) intersection()----> creates a new set with the common elements from both the sets
4)intersection_update()------> applied on a set itself and it also contains the common elements from both the sets
5)symmetric_difference--------> creates a new set with the elements from the both the sets that are not common in between
6)symmetric_difference_update-------> applied on a set itself and it contains elements from the sets that are not common inj between
7)difference------> creates a new set with the elements from a single set that are not common
8) difference_update-----> applied on a set itself and contains elements of a set that are not common

9)isdisjoint()---->checks if there are common elements between two sets
10)issuperset----> checks if a set is a superset of another set
11) issubset-----> checks is a set is subset of another set
12)add------> to add a element into a set

In Python, a set is a collection of unique elements. Sets are used to store multiple items in a single variable. Set items are unordered, unchangeable, and do not allow duplicate values.

Here are some common methods that you can use with sets in Python:

add(): Adds an element to the set
clear(): Removes all the elements from the set
copy(): Returns a copy of the set
difference(): Returns the difference between two or more sets as a new set
difference_update(): Removes the items in this set that are also included in another, specified set
discard(): Removes an element from the set if it is present
intersection(): Returns the intersection of two sets as a new set
intersection_update(): Removes the items in this set that are not present in other, specified sets
isdisjoint(): Returns True if two sets have a null intersection
issubset(): Returns True if another set contains this set
issuperset(): Returns True if this set contains another set
pop(): Removes and returns an arbitary set element. Raise KeyError if the set is empty
remove(): Removes an element from the set. If the element is not present, raises a KeyError
symmetric_difference(): Returns the symmetric difference of two sets as a new set
symmetric_difference_update(): Inserts the symmetric differences from this set and another
union(): Returns the union of sets in a new set
update(): Updates the set with the union of this set and others Sir, please bring a video on the Quick Quiz Fibonacci series program in python! I'm present üíù Hamara Teacher Kesa Ho!*

Likewise, The else with forloop/whileloop also, the else block will be executed, only if the "forloop"/"whileloop" condition checking fails.

If we written break in for loop or while loop then the loop will be terminated unfortunately, without the failed condition checking.

So, There after, the else block will not be executed.

1. We can use else clause with exception handling.
try:
result = 100 / 2
except ZeroDivisionError:
print(f"Division Error")
else:
print("Result is", result)

2. Using the finally clause in exception handling
try:
result = 10 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
print("Division by zero!")
finally:
print("This block of code will always execute.")

3. Raising exceptions using raise
try:
raise ValueError("This is a custom error message.")
except ValueError as e:
print("An error occurred:", str(e)) day 36 class done Harry bhai try and except ki madad sa kia hum cartision product la sakta hein Server logs Government websites par dikhti hai :D thankyou Harry bhai me vs code me try kr rha hoon exception handling isme ptani kyun try and except work nhi kr rhaüò¢ Can we use pound instead to doing all these? plz give info about assertion error The main thing is missing that we don't know what type of exceptions exist

There are several types of errors that can occur in Python:

Syntax errors: These occur when the code is not written in a proper format, and the interpreter is unable to understand it. For example, if you forget to close a parentheses or forget to indent code properly, you will get a syntax error.

Name errors: These occur when you try to use a variable that has not been defined.

Type errors: These occur when you try to perform an operation on a value of the wrong type. For example, if you try to add a string and a number, you will get a type error.

Index errors: These occur when you try to access an element in a list or a string using an index that is out of bounds.

Value errors: These occur when a built-in function receives an argument of the right type, but an inappropriate value.

Attribute errors: These occur when you try to access an attribute of an object that does not exist.

Import errors: These occur when you try to import a module that does not exist or cannot be found.

Key errors: These occur when you try to access a dictionary with a key that does not exist.

File not found errors: These occur when you try to open a file that does not exist or cannot be found.

Indentation errors: These occur when the indentation of the code is not consistent, which can cause the interpreter to behave unexpectedly.

Zero division errors: These occur when you try to divide a number by zero, which is not allowed in Python.

Recursion errors: These occur when a function calls itself recursively, but the base case is not defined, causing the function to call itself indefinitely.

Memory errors: These occur when the program tries to use more memory than the computer has available.

Overflow errors: These occur when a calculation produces a result that is too large to be stored in the allocated memory.

Underflow errors: These occur when a calculation produces a result that is too small to be represented accurately in the allocated memory.

Assertion errors: These occur when an assert statement fails.

Not implemented errors: These occur when a method or function has not been implemented yet.

Runtime errors: These occur while the program is running and can be caused by a variety of factors, such as invalid input, missing resources, or other unforeseen circumstances.

Security errors: These occur when the program tries to perform an action that is not allowed due to security restrictions.

Timeout errors: These occur when a program takes too long to run and exceeds the allotted time limit.

Unbound local errors: These occur when you try to access a local variable before it has been defined.

Internal errors: These occur when the interpreter encounters an unexpected condition that it cannot handle.

External errors: These occur when the program interacts with an external resource (such as a database or a network connection) and something goes wrong.

It is also worth noting that Python allows you to define your own custom errors using the Exception class. This can be useful if you want to create specific error handling logic for your program. In Python, the finally block is designed to be executed no matter what - whether an exception occurs or not, and even if a return statement is encountered in the try or except blocks.

When a return statement is encountered in the try or except block, Python doesn‚Äôt immediately exit the function. Instead, it first executes the finally block, and then it returns from the function.

from tkinter import messagebox

class KBCGameGUI:
def __init__(self, master):
self.master = master
self.master.title("KBC Game")
self.current_question_index = 0
self.score = 0

self.questions = [
["Which language was used to create Facebook", "Java", "Python", "HTML", "Php", "None", 4],

["Which is biggest planet","Earth","Sturn","Pluto","Mars","Jupyter",5],

["Which is hotest planet in our solar system","Earth","Mercury","Pluto","Mars","Jupyter",2],

["Who is the founder of Neurolink Inc","Elone Musk","Warren Buffet","Mark Zukerberg","Satoshi Nakamoto","Stevejobs",1],

["Which is inventor of crypto currency Bitcoin","Satoshi Nakamoto","Elien Wang","Binance","Hamlet Steve","James",1],

["What is formula of Sodium chloride","NACL","CH3","H20","CHE3COOH","H2SO4",1],

["Which Crypto Currency has hightest value","Etherium","BitCoin","XRP","Solana","PEPE",2],

["Which is richest man on earth","Jeff Besos","Bill Gates","Warren Buffet","Hamlet Steve","Elone Musk",5],

["Which won cricket worldcup 2023","Pakistan","Australia","India","Sirilanka","Bangladesh",5],
# ... Add more questions
]

self.levels = [2000, 3000, 4000, 5000, 6000, 7000, 8000, 9000, 10000]

self.create_widgets()

def create_widgets(self):
self.master.configure(bg='#e6f7ff') # Set background color

self.question_label = tk.Label(
self.master, text="", font=("Helvetica", 14), wraplength=400, justify="center", bg='#e6f7ff') # Set question label color
self.question_label.pack(pady=20)

self.option_buttons = []
for i in range(1, 6):
button = tk.Button(
self.master, text="", command=lambda i=i: self.check_answer(i), bg='#80c7e6') # Set button color
button.pack(pady=5)
self.option_buttons.append(button)

self.next_question_button = tk.Button(
self.master, text="Next Question", command=self.next_question, bg='#99ffcc') # Set button color
self.next_question_button.pack(pady=20)

self.update_question()

def update_question(self):
question = self.questions[self.current_question_index]
self.question_label.config(
text=f"{question[0]}\n\n1: {question[1]}\n2: {question[2]}\n3: {question[3]}\n4: {question[4]}\n5: {question[5]}")

for i in range(5):
self.option_buttons[i].config(text=question[i + 1])

def check_answer(self, answer):
correct_answer = self.questions[self.current_question_index][-1]

if answer == correct_answer:
messagebox.showinfo("Correct!", f"Congratulations! You've won Rs {self.levels[self.current_question_index]}")
self.score += self.levels[self.current_question_index]
else:
messagebox.showinfo(
"Incorrect!", f"Sorry, the correct answer was option {correct_answer}. Your final score is Rs {self.score}")
self.reset_game()

def next_question(self):
self.current_question_index += 1

if self.current_question_index < len(self.questions):
self.update_question()
else:
messagebox.showinfo("Game Over", f"Congratulations! You've completed the game. Your final score is Rs {self.score}")
self.reset_game()

def reset_game(self):
self.current_question_index = 0
self.score = 0
self.update_question()


if _name_ == "__main__":

},
]

import string

def random_text_generator(length):
letter = ""
word = ""
for i in range(length):
a = random.randint(1,100)
if a>=1 and a<=13:
letter = 'f'
elif a>13 and a<=24:
letter = 'q'
elif a>24 and a<=33:
letter = 's'
elif a>33 and a<=42:
letter = 'k'
elif a>42 and a<=53:
letter = 'a'
elif a>53 and a<=62:
letter = 'j'
elif a>62 and a<=73:
letter = 'c'
elif a>70 and a<=89:
letter = 'v'
else:
letter = 'i'
word +=letter
return word

def reverse_word(x):
word = ""
for i in range(len(x)):
word += x[len(x)-i-1]
return word

def encoding(str1):
temp = ""
words = ""
words_list = str1.split(" ")
for val in words_list:
if(len(val)>3):
a = random_text_generator(3)
b = random_text_generator(3)
temp = list(val)
x = temp.pop(0)
temp.append(x)
temp = "".join(temp)
temp = a + temp + b
words += temp + " "
else:
temp = reverse_word(val)
words += temp + " "
return words

def decoding(str1):
words_list = str1.split(" ")
words = ""
temp = ""
for val in words_list:
if(len(val)>3):
temp = val[3:]
temp = temp[:-3]
temp = list(temp)
a = temp.pop()
temp.insert(0,a)
temp = "".join(temp)
words += temp + " "
else:
temp = reverse_word(val)
words += temp + " "
return words

import random

def get_random_string(length):
# choose from all lowercase letter
letters = string.ascii_lowercase
result_str = ''.join(random.choice(letters) for i in range(length))
return result_str


def encode(word):
if(len(word)<3): return word[::-1]
else:
word = word[1:len(word)] + word[0]
new_word = get_random_string(3) + word + get_random_string(3)
return new_word

def decode(word):
if(len(word)<3): return word[::-1]
else:
word = word[3:-3]
new_word = word[-1] + word[0:len(word)-1]
return new_word

import random

class Secret_Language:

def __init__(self):
self.code = ""
self.alphabet = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
self.ask = ""

def ask_code_or_decode(self):
# Ask the user whether they want to code or decode
ask = str(input("\nDo you wish to code or decode: "))
if ask == "code":
self.code = str(input("\nEnter Sentence or Word to Code: "))
# Split the input into words
self.code = self.code.split()
self.code_language()
elif ask == "decode":
self.decode = str(input("\nEnter Sentence or word to Decode: "))
# Split the input into words
self.decode = self.decode.split()
self.decode_language()

def code_language(self):
modified_codes = [] # Create a list to store the modified codes
for word in self.code:
code = word
alphabet = 0
if len(code) >= 3:
# Appending first letter at the end
modified_code = code[:0] + code[1:] + code[0]
# Reversing code to append 3 random letters at the start
modified_code = modified_code[::-1]
# Producing the final code
for i in range(3):
# Generate a random letter each time
random_alphabet = random.choice(self.alphabet)
# Appending random letters
modified_code = modified_code + random_alphabet
# Reversing code to append 3 random letters at the end
modified_code = modified_code[::-1]
for i in range(3):
# Generate a random letter each time
random_alphabet = random.choice(self.alphabet)
# Appending random letters
modified_code = modified_code + random_alphabet
else:
# If the word is too short, reverse it
modified_code = code[::-1]
# Store the modified code
modified_codes.append(modified_code)
# Return the modified codes
print("\nConverted to Secret Code: " ," ".join(modified_codes))

def decode_language(self):
# Create a list to store the modified codes
modified_codes = []
for word in self.decode:
code = word
if len(code) >= 3:
# Remove the first letter and the 3rd letter
modified_code = code[:0] + code[3:]
modified_code = modified_code[::-1]
# Remove the last letter and the 4th from the end
modified_code = modified_code[:0] + modified_code[3:]
# Appending last letter at the start
modified_code = modified_code[:0] + modified_code[1:] + modified_code[0]
modified_code = modified_code[::-1]
else:
# If the word is too short, reverse it
modified_code = code[::-1]
# Store the modified code
modified_codes.append(modified_code)
# Return the modified codes
print("\nDecoded from Secret Code: " ," ".join(modified_codes) )

x = Secret_Language()
x.ask_code_or_decode() # code by gouranga-ls

import string
def encode(text):
words = text.split()
encoded_text_words = []
for word in words:
if len(word) < 3:
encoded_text_words.append(word[::-1])
else:
r_ap_last = word[1:] + word[0]
# print(r_ap_last)
random_3_letters = ''
for i in range(0,3):
random_3_letters += random.choice(string.ascii_lowercase)
encoded_text_words.append(random_3_letters + r_ap_last + random_3_letters)
encoded_text = " ".join(encoded_text_words)
return encoded_text

def decode(encoded_text):
words = encoded_text.split()
decoded_text_words = []
for word in words:
if len(word) < 3:
decoded_text_words.append(word[::-1])
else:
r_3_random = word[3:][:-3]
r_l_ap_first = r_3_random[-1] + r_3_random[0:-1]
decoded_text_words.append(r_l_ap_first)
decoded_text = " ".join(decoded_text_words)
return decoded_text

1. words having 3 or less characters will be reversed
2. Words having more than 3 characters, remove the last letter, append it to the last,
then insert 3 random letters to both beginning and end.
3. so while decoding, either the message is simply reversed or,
fist and lst 3 characters are removed and then last character isremoved,
and added to first, depending on the number of letters
4. remember that after coding, a word of 4-9 letters doesnt exist, as the 4 letter

import random
import string


user_input = input("Enter the message : ")
user_input_list = user_input.replace(',', ' , ').replace('.', ' . ').split()


def reverse(x):
'''This is to reverse the word when called'''

return x[::-1]


def random_letters():
'''This is to generate three letters at random'''
letter = ""
for _ in range(3):
letter += random.choice(string.ascii_letters)
return letter


def code(text):
'''This is to code the given message'''
output = []
for i in text:
if len(i) <= 3:
output.append(reverse(i))
else:
first = i[0]
word = random_letters() + i[1:] + first + random_letters()
output.append(word)

coded = ''
for word in output:
coded += ' ' + word

return coded


def decode(text):
'''This is to decode the messsage'''
output = []
for i in text:
if len(i) <= 3:
output.append(reverse(i))
else:
main_word = i[3:-3]
first = main_word[-1]
word = first + main_word[:-1]
output.append(word)

decoded = ''
for word in output:
decoded += ' ' + word

return decoded


command = input(
"What do you want to do, code or decode? Type 'code' or 'decode' : ")

if command.lower() == "code":
print("The coded message is :\n", code(user_input_list))
elif command.lower() == "decode":
print("The original message was :\n", decode(user_input_list))
else:
print("Wrong command given")

def encrypt(message):
if len(message) < 2:
return message[::-1]
elif len(message) >= 3:
first_letter = message[0]
encrypted_message = message[1:len(message)][::-1]
random_letters = ''.join(random.choices('abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz', k=3))
return random_letters + encrypted_message + first_letter + random_letters

def decrypt(message):
random_letters = message[:3]
message = message[3:-3]
if (len(message) < 2):
return message[::-1]
elif (len(message) >= 3):
last_letter = message[-1]
decrypted_message = message[:-1][::-1]
return last_letter + decrypted_message

def add_random_letters(word, num_letters):
new_word = word
letters = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
prime_number = 31 # A prime number for generating randomness
random_seed = len(word) + num_letters # Seed for randomness

# Add random letters at the start
for _ in range(num_letters):
random_index = random_seed % len(letters)
random_letter = letters[random_index]
new_word = random_letter + new_word
random_seed = (random_seed * prime_number) % len(letters)

# Add random letters at the end
for _ in range(num_letters):
random_index = random_seed % len(letters)
random_letter = letters[random_index]
new_word += random_letter
random_seed = (random_seed * prime_number) % len(letters)

return new_word

def generate_random_characters(char_length):
alpha_num = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmopqrstuvwxyz0123456789"
random_str = ""
for i in range(char_length):
random_str += random.choice(alpha_num)
return random_str

splited_message = message.split(" ")
encoded_message = []
for word in splited_message:
if len(word) < 3:
encoded_message.append(word[::-1])
else:
temp_word = ""
temp_word += generate_random_characters(3)
temp_word += word[1:]
temp_word += word[0]
temp_word += generate_random_characters(3)
encoded_message.append(temp_word)
return " ".join(encoded_message)

def decode(encoded_message):
splited_message = encoded_message.split(" ")
decoded_message = []
for word in splited_message:
if len(word) < 3:
decoded_message.append(word[::-1])
else:
removed_random_chars = word[3:-3]
temp_word = ""
temp_word += removed_random_chars[-1]
temp_word += removed_random_chars[0:-1]
decoded_message.append(temp_word)
return " ".join(decoded_message)

random_string1 = ''.join(random.choice(available_letters) for _ in range(3))
encoded_string = random_string + temp_string + random_string1

print("The Final Encoded string is ", encoded_string)
return encoded_string
else:
encoded_string = ''.join(reversed(word))
print("The Final Encoded string is ",encoded_string)
return encoded_string


def decode(to_decode):
if(len(to_decode)>3):
temp = to_decode[3:len(to_decode)-3]
decoded_string = temp[len(temp)-1] + temp[:len(temp)-1]
print("The Final Decoded string is ", decoded_string)

else:
decoded_string = ''.join(reversed(to_decode))
print("The Final Decoded string is ", decoded_string)



print("Enter the string to be Encoded")

word = input()

to_decode = encode(word) #calling the function to encode

decode(to_decode) #calling the function to decode import random
import string

text = list(input("Enter the message: "))
choose = int(
input("Enter 1 to Encode the message and enter 2 to decode the message"))


def encode(message):
if len(message) >= 3:
message.append(message[0])
# message.remove(message[0])
message = message[1:] + [
random.choice(string.ascii_letters) for _ in range(3)
]
message = [random.choice(string.ascii_letters) for _ in range(3)] + message
else:
message.reverse()
return ''.join(message)


def decode(message):
if len(message) < 3:
message.reverse()
else:
message = message[3:-3]
message.insert(0, message[-1])
message.pop()
return ''.join(message)


if choose == 1:
encoded_msg = encode(text)
print("Encoded message:", encoded_msg)
elif choose == 2:
decoded_msg = decode(text)
print("Decoded message:", decoded_msg)
else:
print("Invalid choice") def encryption():
a=str(input("Enter the message to encrypt:"))
# print(a.split())
b=a.split()
for i,x in enumerate(b):
word=b[i]

if len(word)>2:
word1=word[0:2]
word2=word[2:]+word1
print("be"+word2 , end=" ")
else:
word1=word[0]
word2=word[1:]+word1
print("be"+word2 , end=" ")



def decryption():
a=str(input("Enter the message to decrypt:"))
# print(a.split())
b=a.split()
for i,x in enumerate(b):
word=b[i]

if len(word)>4:
word1=word[len(word)-2:len(word)]
word2=word1+word[2:len(word)-2]
print(word2 , end=" ")
else:
word1=word[len(word)-1:len(word)]
word2=word1+word[2:len(word)-1]
print(word2 , end=" ")

print("Secret Language Of Shimla:\n" )
import time
time.sleep(1.5)
A=int(input("You want to (1) Encrypt a message or (2) Decrypt a message (1 or 2) : "))
if A==1:
encryption()
elif A==2:
decryption()
else:
print("Please answer with 1 or 2 only")

Thanks for keeping things simple! Guys... if you are getting errors (like activation not enabled, scripting is disabled) in windows... do this..

** Delete the myevn file first** or you can totally jump into the existing directory through command prompt

1. close the powershell
2. go and open command prompt
3. go to the directory using cd command. .. (for example if I want to create a the environment in python-enviro in D directory, type D: enter and then cd python-enviro <enter>

4. run the command python -m venv myevn <enter>(you can give any name in the place of myenv, basically a folder will be created with this name)
5. type cd myevn <enter>(or the name you have given)
6. type cd Scripts <enter>

7. type activate <enter> (or deactivate to deactivate)

| --- | --- |

| virtualenv | gives all the commands |
| virtualenv <env name> | creates virtual env with the specified name |
| .\<venv name>\Scripts\activate | activates the venv |
| pip install <appname> | install the app |
| pip show <module name> | checks the version of installed module |
| pip list commands | gives the version installed of all packages in the venv |
| pip freeze> requirements.txt | creates a new file named requirements with all the names and version of packages |

print(" ".join(k)) I am a bit disappointed at myself for not being able to solve the problem myself It's ot clear I have a doubt how come the list became the string a gain >?? I'm present. 11:27 - Purely random karne ke 2 ways hai. import random statement to dono me hi aayegi.

1. Import string. Is module ke andar ek ascii_letters naam ka object hota hai, which is a string of all the alphabets in lowercase and uppercase. We have 26 alphabets in total. Lowercase and Uppercase mila ke 26*2=52 hote hai. To 0-51 me se koi bhi 3 numbers generate karke slicing karke us index ka character utha lenge.

Example,
import random, string
x="String"
for i in range(3):
x = string.ascii_letters[random.randint(0, 51)] + x
for i in range(3):
x = x + string.ascii_letters[random.randint(0, 51)]


2. Using chr() function : chr() function given number ke corresponding ASCII value return kar deta hai. To ham 0-25 ek random number generate karwa lenge, then usme 65 add kar lenge. Then resulting number ko chr() ke andar pass kar denge. Same cheez ko 3 baar start ke liye and 3 baar end ke liye kar lenge,


Example,
import random
x = "String"
for i in range(3):
x = chr(65+random.randint(0,25)) + x
for i in range(3):
x = x + chr(65+random.randint(0,25))


3. 2nd wale me uppercase and lowercase ko alag alag bhi kar sakte hai.

Example,
import random
x = "String"
for i in range(3):
up = random.randint(0,1)
if up==1:
x = chr(65+random.randint(0,25)) + x
else:
x = chr(97+random.randint(0,25)) + x
for i in range(3):
up = random.randint(0,1)
if up==1:
x = x + chr(65+random.randint(0,25))
else:
x = x + chr(97+random.randint(0,25)) def main(inp,option):
output= ""
try:
if(option == "coding"):
output = coding(inp)
elif(option == "decoding"):
output = decoding(inp)
except:
print("Select the correct option")
inp = input("Enter the string")
option = input("Enter the task coding/decoding").lower()
return output

def coding(inp):
opt = ""
if(len(inp)>=3):
opt = "*&^" + inp[1:] + inp[0] + "#^%"
else:
opt = inp.reverse()
return opt


def decoding(inp):
opt,raw_inp = "",""
if(len(inp)>=3):
raw_inp = inp[3:-3]
opt = raw_inp[-1] + raw_inp[0:-1]
else:

import string

# Function to generate a random word of a given length
def random_word(length):
return ''.join(random.choice(string.ascii_lowercase) for _ in range(length))

def encode(text):
words = text.split()
encoded_words = []

for word in words:
if len(word) <= 3:
# Reverse the word
word = word[::-1]
else:
# Swap the first and last characters and insert random words at the beginning and end
random_start = random_word(3)
random_end = random_word(3)
word = random_start + word[-1] + word[1:-1] + word[0] + random_end

encoded_words.append(word)

encoded_text = ' '.join(encoded_words)

return encoded_text



def decode(text):
text_words=text.split()
decoded_words=[]
for word in text_words:
if len(word)<=3:
word=word[::-1]
else:
word1 = word[3:-3]
word=word1[-1] + word1[1:-1] + word1[0]
decoded_words.append(word)
print(decoded_words)

decoded_text = ' '.join(decoded_words)
print(decoded_text)

return decoded_text

encode_or_decode = input("Do you want to encode or decode? ")

if encode_or_decode.lower() == "encode":
text = input("Enter the text you want to encode: ")
encoded_text = encode(text)
print("Encoded text:", encoded_text)

elif encode_or_decode.lower() == "decode":
text = input("Enter the text you want to decode: ")
decoded_text = decode(text)
print("Decoded text:", decoded_text)

else:
print("Invalid choice. Please enter 'encode' or 'decode'.") Harry bhai vo r1 and r2 ko randomize krneko bola tha na ye ha vo üëáüëáüëá

import string
import random

message = input('Write a message here :')
print('Initial message is ', message)
#Encoding
message = message.split()


def Encoding(message):
if (len(message) < 3):
ENmessage = list(message)
ENmessage.reverse()
ENmessage = ''.join(ENmessage)
print('Encoded message is: ', ENmessage)
return ENmessage
else:
ENmessage = message[1:] + message[0]
# print(random.choice(string.ascii_letters))
for i in range(1, 4):
ENmessage = random.choice(
string.ascii_letters) + ENmessage + random.choice(string.ascii_letters)
print('Encoded message is: ', ENmessage)
return ENmessage


#Decoding
def Decoding(ENmessage):
if (len(ENmessage) < 3):
Dmessage = list(ENmessage)
Dmessage.reverse()
Dmessage = ''.join(Dmessage)
print('Decoded message is: ', Dmessage)
return Dmessage
else:
Dmessage = ENmessage[3:len(ENmessage) - 3]
Dmessage = Dmessage[-1] + Dmessage[0:len(Dmessage) - 1]
print('Decoded message is: ', Dmessage)
return Dmessage


helper = ''

# Example of map
"""
def cube(x):
return x*x*x

l = [1, 2, 4, 6, 4, 3]

# newl = []

# for item in l:
# newl.append(cube(item))

newl = list(map(cube, l))
print(newl)
"""
"""
Output:
[1, 8, 64, 216, 64, 27]
"""

# another example of map
"""
# list of numbers
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Double each number using map function
doubled = map(lambda x: x*2, numbers)

print(list(doubled))
"""
"""
Output:
[2, 4, 6, 8, 10]
"""


# Example of filter
"""
# list of numbers
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Get only the even numbers using the filter function
evens = filter(lambda x: x%2==0, numbers)

# print the even numbers
print(list(evens))
"""
"""
Output:
[2, 4]
"""


# example of reduce
"""
from functools import reduce

# list of numbers
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# calculate the sum of the numbers using the reduce function
sum = reduce(lambda x, y: x+y, numbers)

# print the sum
print(sum)
"""
"""
Output:
15

This day is technical theoretic to understand ! The best part of the video is, I am not playing with you I'm present. for tuple a is b - false in colab and in replit it is true why? map muje samaj nehi aia üíï day 54 Sir I am present A = (1,2)
B = (1,2)
print(A is B)
O/p :
False
This is not working in Google Colab and in VS Code but in Replit it is giving (True) for these statements. Reason ????? If we evaluate the below code
a = (1,2)
b = (1,2)
print(a is b)

The answer is True in some IDE's like PyCham.
The answer is False in CMD, Mac Terminal or Jupyter.
same id for complex number and float numbers. This is because Python my default allocate two same tuples, complex numbers and float numbers to different memory location but IDE's like like PyCharm, they might have specific optimisations or configurations which allocate in same memory location.

@CodeWithHarry He is not good.Harray bhai is best Check memory location of any variable by using print(id(variablename)) by which you can properly understand( is vs ' ==' ) # 'is' vs '==' in Python

"""
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]

print(a == b)
print(a is b)
"""
"""
Output:
True
False
"""


# another example
"""
a = 'Hello'
b = 'Hello'

computer_score = 0

print(f"Computer chose: {computer_choice}")

if user_choice == computer_choice:
print("It's a tie!")
elif (
(user_choice == 'snake' and computer_choice == 'water') or
(user_choice == 'water' and computer_choice == 'gun') or
(user_choice == 'gun' and computer_choice == 'snake')
):
print("You win!")
user_score += 1
else:
print("You lose!")
computer_score += 1

print(f"Your score: {user_score}, Computer score: {computer_score}")

play_again = input("Do you want to play again? (yes/no): ").lower()
if play_again != 'yes':
break

def get_valid_input(player_name):
while True:
try:
val = int(input(f"{player_name} choose a value from Snake=0 or Water=1 or Gun=2: "))
if val not in [0, 1, 2]:
raise ValueError("Invalid input. Please enter 0, 1, or 2.")
return val
except ValueError as e:
print(f"Error: {e}")

def func(matrix, items, plays, p1, p2):

p1c = 0
p2c = 0
play = plays

while play:
valp1 = get_valid_input(p1)
valp2 = get_valid_input(p2)

if matrix[valp1][valp2] == 'D':
print("It's a draw")
p2c += 1
p1c += 1
elif matrix[valp1][valp2] == 'W':
print(f"{p1} won this round with {items[valp1]} by {items[valp2]} ")
p1c += 1
else:
print(f"{p2} won this round with {items[valp2]} by {items[valp1]} ")
p2c += 1

play -= 1

if p2c > p1c:
print(f"{p2} wins the game by {p2c - p1c} points in a point total of {plays}")
elif p2c < p1c:
print(f"{p1} wins the game by {p1c - p2c} points in a point total of {plays}")
else:
print(f"It's a draw for both {p1} and {p2}")

"""

while (choice=='y'):

u_input = int(input("Type 1 for Snake or 2 for Water or 3 for Gun: "))

print()
print("*** Game Drawn *****")

# condition 2: when player will win
elif (u_input == user[0] and c_input == computer[1]) or (u_input == user[1] and c_input == computer[2]) or (u_input == user[2] and c_input == computer[0]):
system('cls')
print(f"Your Choice: {options[u_input-1]} VS Computer's Choice: {options[c_input-1]}")
print()
print("*** You Won *****")

# default condition: when player will loose
else:
system('cls')
print(f"Your Choice: {options[u_input-1]} VS Computer's Choice: {options[c_input-1]}")
print()
print("*** You Lost *****")

print("\n")

from random import choice

# global variables to keep a track of scores of both player and computer.
player_score = 0
comp_score = 0


# this is the main function which interprets the final winning or loosing of player or computer.
def score_decider(player_choice, comp_choice):
# global variables declared inside the function.
global player_score
global comp_score

# list of choices made for further use.
choice_list = ["snake", "water", "gun"]

# a comprehended list of all the possible inputs by player and computer together.
case_lst = [
player_choice.lower() == choice_list[i]
and comp_choice.lower() == choice_list[j]
for i in range(3)
for j in range(3)
]

# a list of the scores according to the corresponding above possibilities.
score_lst = [[0, 0], [1, 0], [0, 1], [0, 1], [0, 0], [1, 0], [1, 0], [0, 1], [0, 0]]

# finalising the scores according to the input.
for index, i in enumerate(case_lst):
if i == True:
player_score = player_score + score_lst[index][0]
comp_score = comp_score + score_lst[index][1]


# introductry game line.
print("\nWelcome to the SNAKE-WATER-GUN (Computer V Human) Simulator.\n")

# list of choices made for further use.
comp_choice_lst = ["snake", "water", "gun"]

# a for loop to excecute 5 rounds of the game.
for i in range(5):
# inputting player choice
print("Enter your choice : ", end="")

# While loop for error handling.
while True:
player_choice = input()
if (
player_choice.lower() == "snake"
or player_choice.lower() == "water"
or player_choice.lower() == "gun"
):
break
else:
print("Please enter a valid input : ", end="")

# use of choice(), so that the comuter chooses the input randomly.
comp_choice = choice(comp_choice_lst)
print(f"Computer entered the choice : {comp_choice}\n")
score_decider(player_choice, comp_choice)

# final score displayed after all the rounds.
print(f"The final score (Player, Computer) ---> ({player_score}, {comp_score})\n")

# Winner decleration.
if player_score > comp_score:
print("Player won the game!!\n")
elif player_score < comp_score:
print("Computer won the game!!\n")
else:
print("It's a draw.\n") import random

def play_game(player_choice):
choices = ["Snake", "Water", "Gun"]
computer_choice = random.choice(choices)

print(f"Your choice: {player_choice}")
print(f"Computer's choice: {computer_choice}")

if player_choice == computer_choice:
return "It's a tie!"
elif player_choice == "Snake":
if computer_choice == "Water":
return "You win! Snake drinks water."
else:
return "You lose! Gun kills the snake."
elif player_choice == "Water":
if computer_choice == "Gun":
return "You win! Water puts out the gun."
else:
return "You lose! Snake drinks water."
elif player_choice == "Gun":
if computer_choice == "Snake":
return "You win! Gun kills the snake."
else:
return "You lose! Water puts out the gun."
else:
return "Invalid choice. Please choose Snake, Water, or Gun."

if (comp == 2 and user == 0):
return -1

return 1

def user_choice():
user_input = input("Select Rock,Paper,scissor:")
if user_input in ["rock", "paper", "scissor"]:
return user_input.lower()
else:
print("Invalid choice")


def computer_choice():
computer_input = random.choice(["rock", "paper", "scissor"])
return computer_input


def winner_determine(user_choice, computer_choice):
if user_choice == computer_choice:
return "Draw"
elif (user_choice == "rock" and computer_choice == "scissor" or \
user_choice == "scissor" and computer_choice == "paper" or\
user_choice == "paper" and computer_choice == "stone"):
return "You Won"

else:
return "Computer Won"


def play_game():
user_choic = user_choice()
computer_choic = computer_choice()
print(f"\nYou Choose: {user_choic} Computer Choose: {computer_choic}")

x=winner_determine(user_choic,computer_choic)
print(x)

else:

print("\nGame over!")

elif user_score < comp_score:
print(f"The computer won {comp_score} rounds and you won {user_score} rounds.")
else:
print(f"It's a draw! Both you and the computer won {user_score} rounds.")

# Creating Snake, Water and Gun game

import random
import time

options = ["Snake", "Water", "Gun"]
chances = [
[[[0, 0], "D"], [[0, 1], "W"], [[0, 2], "L"]],
[[[1, 0], "L"], [[1, 1], "D"], [[1, 2], "W"]],
[[[2, 0], "W"], [[2, 1], "L"], [[2, 2], "D"]],
]

num = 0
player = -1
computer = -1
result = []


def byPlayer():
global num
global player
global result
print("Chose one:")
for option in options:
num = num + 1
num = 1 if num > 3 else num
print(str(num) + ")", option)

value = int(input("Enter anyone option number :"))
if value in (1, 2, 3):
result.append(value - 1)
print(options[value - 1])


def byComputer():
global result
randomNum = random.randint(0, 2)
result.append(randomNum)
print(options[randomNum])


def resultChecker():
print("Result:")
for possibilities in chances:
for possibility in possibilities:
if possibility[0] == result:
if possibility[1] == "L":
print("You Got Lose")
elif possibility[1] == "D":
print("The Match Got Draw")
else:
print("You Got Win")
result.clear()
break


rounds = int(input("How Many rounds do you want to play : "))
playedRounds = 0
while True:
playedRounds = playedRounds + 1
byPlayer()
print("Computer's Turn")
time.sleep(2)
byComputer()
print("The Result is on a way...")
time.sleep(3)
resultChecker()
if playedRounds == rounds:
break "hann to guyss mai aagya hu day bachpan ki repl mai" -- ü§£ü§£ thanks done!! import random

def get_player_choice():
choice = input("Enter 's' for snake, 'w' for water, 'g' for gun: ")
return choice

def get_computer_choice():
choices = ['s', 'w', 'g']
choice = random.choice(choices)
return choice

def play_game(player_choice, computer_choice):
if player_choice == computer_choice:
print("Tie!")
elif (player_choice == 's' and computer_choice == 'w') or (player_choice == 'w' and computer_choice == 'g') or (player_choice == 'g' and computer_choice == 's'):
print("Congratulations! You win.")
else:
print("Sorry, you lose.")

def play_again():
play_again = input("Do you want to play again? (y/n): ")
if play_again == 'y':
return True
else:
return False

# Main game loop
while True:
player_choice = get_player_choice()
computer_choice = get_computer_choice()
print(f"You chose {player_choice}. The computer chose {computer_choice}.")
play_game(player_choice, computer_choice)
if not play_again():
break

'''This function returns the key if value is given and vice versa. returns key if 2nd argument is True'''
for key,value in reference.items():
if not j:
if key.lower() == val.lower():
return value
else:
if value == val:
return key

# Getters and Setters in Python

# example of Getters
"""
class MyClass:
def __init__(self, value):
self._value = value

def show(self):
print(f"value of object is {self._value}")
@property
def ten_value(self):
return 10*self._value

obj = MyClass(10)
print(obj.ten_value)
obj.show()
"""
"""
Output:
100
value of object is 10
"""

# another example of getters
"""
class MyClass:
def __init__(self, value):
self._value = value

@property
def value(self):
return self._value

obj = MyClass(10)
print(obj.value)
"""
"""
Output:
10
"""


# Example of Setters
"""
class MyClass:
def __init__(self, value):
self._value=value

@property
def value(self):
return self._value

@value.setter
def value(self, new_value):
self._value = new_value

def show(self):
print(f"value is {self._value}")

obj = MyClass(10)
obj.value = 20
obj.show()
print(obj.value)
"""
"""
Output:
value is 20
20
"""

# another example of Setters in Python
"""
class MyClass:
def __init__(self, value):
self._value = value

#getter
@property
def value(self):
return self._value
#setter
@value.setter
def value(self, new_value):
self._value = new_value

obj = MyClass(10)
obj.value = 20
print(obj.value)
"""
"""
Output:
20

class employee:
def __init__(self, salary) -> None:
self.salary = salary
self.bonussalary = 700
def show(self):
print(f"salary is {self.salary}")
print(f"bonussalary is {self.bonussalary}")
@property
def totalsalary(self):
return self.salary + self.bonussalary
@totalsalary.setter
def totalsalary(self, newtotalsalary):
self.salary = newtotalsalary - self.bonussalary
if _name_ == '__main__':
employee = employee(11000)
employee.totalsalary = 10000
print(employee.totalsalary)
employee.show()

If we just change the name of class, all places where the class was previously mentioned will raise an error. But even if we use inheritance to create a new class containing the prev class, it still raises an error if we use any functions of the new class using prev class name. So, in the eg in this vid, we have to again change wherever employee was mentioned to programmer to access new programmer methods.
But we could just change the name of employee to programmer in the class def, as well as when we call the class methods and that would be alright
